newsitem.title: Malta: Europe fails to bridge Palestinian-Israeli gap.
newsitem.headline: Europe fails to bridge Palestinian-Israeli gap.

text.p: European efforts to bring together Palestinians and Israelis floundered on Tuesday despite intensive negotiations, Palestinian officials said.

The European Union had hoped to bring Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy together to discuss the Middle East peace crisis on a fringes of a European-Mediterranean conference in Malta.

"The chances of a meeting between Mr Levy and the president almost do not exist. The president is not going to meet with Mr Levy because of certain issues that need to be discussed," Arafat spokesman Marwan Kanafani told Reuters.
Kanafani said even a meeting between Levy and a Palestinian minister now looked unlikely.
"There was a quasi-agreement that Levy would meet a Palestinian minister. The president authorised a meeting. Now there has been a retraction on this position," he said.
Earlier, Palestinian Planning Minister Nabil Shaath said he would meet Levy.

In his speech to the Malta conference, Levy urged the Palestinians to resume negotiations without conditions. Diplomats say the Palestinians are pressing for an Israeli gesture, especially on Israel's construction of a settlement in East Jerusalem which has plunged the peace process into crisis.
After a plenary conference session, 15 European ministers met separately with Arafat and then with Levy to try to bridge differences.
None of the ministers, nor the Palestinian president, made any statements on leaving the talks.

Earlier, Arafat and Levy briefly shook hands during a reception hosted by Maltese Prime Minister Alfred Sant. It was the highest level contact since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gave the go-ahead for the settlement.
But the rancour returned as Arafat and Levy addressed the conference.

"With the current Israeli government we have faced many obstacles and impediments," Arafat said. "Instead of continuing to build and reinforce fruitful cooperation and mutual respect ... the Israeli government continues its settlement policy.
"We have been running around in closed circles without reaching any kind of positive agreement."

In response, Levy appealed for "the Palestinian Authority to broadcast, to publicise an unequivocably clear message against terrorism, refuting terrorism, returning to the dialogue, making the peace objective a common goal"
Despite the efforts of the European Commission to promote the Malta conference as a showcase for EU-Mediterranean cooperation, the Middle East crisis dominated.

In recognition of the gravity of the crisis, Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van Mierlo -- the conference chairman -- agreed to give double speaking time to Levy, Arafat and Algeria, coordinator of the Arab group.
With other ministers overstepping their alloted time, the meeting adjourned at 1615 GMT with nine delegations still to be heard. It will resume on Wednesday morning.
EU efforts to bring about a breakthrough in the Middle East are being matched by U.S. efforts to end the impase.
On Monday, U.S. Secretary of State Madeliene Albright despatched envoy Dennis Ross back to the region for talks with Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

Senior Arab officials met earlier on Tuesday and Algerian Foreign Minister Ahmed Attaf said they wanted a reference to the Middle East stalemate in the final statement, but EU officials said they would try avoid this.
"We want the final declaration to make a reference to this situation and express a position regarding the stalemate the peace process is facing." Attaf said.

Other controversies, bracketed in a recent draft of the final statement, are over human rights, recognition of NGOs (non-governmental organisations) and the rights of emigrants -- mainly a reference to foreigners working in Europe.
